Award.AwardTitle: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Ocean Instrumentation for UNOLS fleet CY 2020-2021
Award.AbstractNarration: A request is made to fund Oceanographic Instrumentation on R/V Atlantis, a 274-foot general purpose research vessel, and R/V Armstrong, a 238-foot multidisciplinary vessel. Both are operated by WHOI as part of the U.S. Academic Research Fleet (ARF) which is scheduled by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Both are owned by the U.S. Navy, have state-of-the-art instrumentation and support all disciplines of oceanographic research. The vessels work in all the worldâ€™s oceans supporting science funded primarily by U.S government agencies. R/V Atlantis is specifically outfitted for launching and servicing Alvin, the human occupied submersible as well as other vehicles of the National Deep Submergence Facility (NDSF). <br/><br/>In 2019, R/V Atlantis completed 284 days at sea. NSF funded projects accounted for 90% of the total sailing schedule (254 days). In 2020, Atlantis is scheduled for 138 days with NSF accounting for 72 of those or 52%. R/V Armstrong sailed 217 total days in 2019 and 43 of these, 20%, were for NSF. Additionally, 78 days (36%) were for NSF-OOI. The vessel is scheduled for 295 days in 2020, 25% of which (59 days) are for NSF and 33% (79 days) are for NSF OOI.<br/><br/>With this proposal, WHOI provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Instrumentation:<br/><br/>3) Hidex 300SL automatic LSC $128,175<br/>(3) McLane Submersible Bio Pumps $122,475<br/>(1) DAVPR Battery Case $6,406<br/>(2) EK80 portable calibration systems $5,992<br/> $263,048<br/><br/>Broader Impacts<br/>The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2020, NSF funded WHOI for two Hidex 300SL automatic Liquid Scintillation Counters (LSC) and three Large Volume McLane Pumps (LVP).

Liquid Scintillation Counters (LSCs)

Benchtop LSCs with TDCR technology and MikroWin software are used to support assessment of isotope counting in a variety of ocean-based experiments. One of the 300SL units is permanently installed in the WHOI portable isotope van; the other unit is in a shore-based hot laboratory, prepared to be loaded onto any ship in need. The shore-based unit is also available for any post-cruise processing needs that cannot be completed while underway. Importantly, the shore unit brings WHOI into compliance with state mandated redundancy for radiation safety and serves as a secondary unit if an expedition requires multiple LSCs. A cart, dedicated computer, and lift table were purchased for the shore-based unit to live on.

 One of the two LSCs is a refurbished model. The purchase of the refurbished unit saved a substantial amount of money which was reallocated towards the purchase of an additional single-channel unit and for the fabrication of an LSC stand and mount. The single-channel unit is critical instrumentation kept in the portable isotope laboratory as emergency backup in the event of multi-channel unit failure while at sea. The single-channel is dually important for conducting swipe tests that ensure isotopes are not tracked throughout the ship. The fabricated stand for mounting the LSCs is critical for keeping the units in safe working conditions off the floor of the isotope van. The stand increases air flow and cooling ability around the unit and protects it from water intrusion in the event of a spill or leak while in transit or use.

 Both LSC units were purchased and fully installed by January 2021. To date, the portable isotope van has been installed on RV ATLANTIS and is in use on a Canadian DFO sponsored cruise in the North Atlantic. The next anticipated use is on an NSF-OCE-BO sponsored cruise with Maria Pachiadaki in early 2023. The LSC will also support Daniel Fornari’s NSF-OCE-MGG cruise which is planned to include natural abundance C14 experiments. The LSC availability aboard allows for swipes to be run and all spaces on the ship thoroughly examined for background levels of C14, in addition to Miami SWAB results. Because the ATLANTIS schedule is planned to be abroad over the majority of the 2022-2023 winter, the isotope van and associated LSC will remain aboard to support all science radiation needs. The shore-based unit is keeping WHOI in state mandated radiation safety compliance and is ready to be put into use aboard any UNOLS vessel that may be in need.

 Large Volume McLane Pumps (LVPs)

Prior to receiving the 2020 OI award, the requested McLane pumps were immediately needed for time sensitive cruises and therefore were purchased with program manager approval on a separate NSF award. WHOI could not transfer the previously purchased McLane pumps to this award due to the timing of the purchase and the receipt of the award. Therefore, the funding granted in this award was used for related OI items that are shared-use.

 The funds awarded were reallocated to other time sensitive and critical OI-related projects, the primary of which was $57.5K for LVP repairs and spares parts for existing units. The remaining half of the funds were used on repairs and spares for CTD components and upgraded WetPlug conversions on our existing systems. The last few thousand dollars were spent on salinometer repairs and a DAVPR battery case that had been previously requested in the original 2020 OI proposal.

The funds awarded in this proposal have been expended at this time.
